description: From buffe (“leather”), from Middle French buffle (“buffalo”).

adjectives.description: buff (comparative buffer or more buff, superlative buffest or most buff)

entries.meaning: (color) Of the color of buff leather, a brownish yellow.
(bodybuilding) Unusually muscular.
examples: The bouncer was a big, buff dude with tattoos, a shaved head, and a serious scowl.

entries.meaning: (slang) Physically attractive.
Undyed leather from the skin of buffalo or similar animals.
A tool, often one covered with buff leather, used for polishing.
(color) A brownish yellow colour.
A military coat made of buff leather.
(informal) A person who is very interested in a particular subject.
examples: Synonyms: enthusiast, aficionado; see also Thesaurus:fan
He’s a real history buff. He knows everything there is to know about the civil war.

entries.meaning: (video games, role-playing games) An effect that makes a character or item stronger.
examples: I just picked up an epic damage buff! Let's go gank the other team!

entries.meaning: (rail transport) Compressive coupler force that occurs during a slack bunched condition.
(colloquial) The bare skin.
The greyish viscid substance constituting the buffy coat.
Any substance used to dilute (street) drugs in order to increase profits.
examples: Police say this 20 ton hydraulic jack was used to press mixtures of cocaine and “buff” into brick.

verbs.description: buff (third-person singular simple present buffs, present participle buffing, simple past and past participle buffed)

entries.meaning: To polish and make shiny by rubbing.
examples: Synonyms: wax, shine, polish, furbish, burnish
He was already buffing the car's hubs.

entries.meaning: (video games, role-playing games) To make a character or an item stronger.
examples: The enchanter buffed the paladin to prepare him to fight the dragon.
I noticed that the pistols were buffed in the update.

entries.meaning: (medical slang) To modify a medical chart, especially in a dishonest manner.

description: Old French bufer (“to cuff, buffet”). See buffet (“a blow”).

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A buffet; a blow.

verbs.description: buff (third-person singular simple present buffs, present participle buffing, simple past and past participle buffed)

entries.meaning: To strike.

description: From Middle English buffen (“to stutter, stammer”), from Old English byffan (“to mumble, mutter”), from Proto-West Germanic *bubjaną, from Proto-Indo-European *bʰeyH- (“to fear, to be afraid”). More at bive (“tremble, shake”) and bever.

verbs.description: buff (third-person singular simple present buffs, present participle buffing, simple past and past participle buffed)

entries.meaning: (dialectal or obsolete) To stammer, stutter
(informal) A buffalo, or the meat of a buffalo.
examples: […]  diced buff (buffalo) meat, usually heavily spiced  […]

entries.meaning: (uncommon) Alternative form of buffe (“face armor”)
examples: For they had helmets on their heads, fashioned like wild beast's necks, and strange beavers or buffs to the same, and wore on their helmets great high plumes of feathers, as they had been wings :  […]
